AttackerCapabilities: Identifying HTTP Desync Attack CL.TE scenario

Steps.Description: Identify interesting HTTP headers in the responses

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The interesting HTTP headers may reveal information about the infrastructure and potential vulnerabilities.
StepDetails.Action: Analyze the responses and identify the Server, Via, and X-Served-By headers.
StepDetails.Result: The headers indicate the presence of a proxy server (haproxy) and application server (gunicorn).

Steps.Description: Recognize the HTTP Desync Attack CL.TE scenario

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The architecture and response headers suggest the possibility of an HTTP Desync Attack CL.TE scenario.
StepDetails.Action: Refer to external resources to understand the scenario.
StepDetails.Result: Confirmation that the scenario is an HTTP Desync Attack CL.TE.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: Crafting a specific HTTP request with a modified Transfer-Encoding header may exploit the HTTP Desync Attack CL.TE scenario.
StepDetails.Action: Create a POST request with a modified Transfer-Encoding header and send it to the /files/ endpoint.
StepDetails.Result: Successful creation of an object in the application.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: By sending a GET request to the /files/ endpoint with the specified GUID, the object can be retrieved.
StepDetails.Action: Send a GET request to the /files/ endpoint with the specified GUID.
StepDetails.Result: Successful retrieval of the object, which contains the flag.
